citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The right eye of an adult male French Bulldog (ID# 8957) contained discharge and was not being treated. Mild amounts of
yellow-green discharge were seen adjacent to the right eye. The eyelids of the right eye also appear to possibly be folding
in on the eye (entropion). The animal was not seen scratching or irritating the site and was not squinting. The licensee
states they have not been treating the eye. Failure to treat problems of animal health can lead to delays in providing
proper care to animals resulting in worsening of their condition. The licensee must maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
The licensee must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times. Correct by ensuring that the
animal is examined and treated by a licensed veterinarian.

The licensee is not following the vaccination schedule in the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC):
-Seven puppies (ID# 8970,8951,8975,8943,8934,8955,8965) born 1/10/2024 received a 5-way vaccine on 2/23/2024 and
then on 3/9/2024. The PVC prescribes for the 5-way vaccine for puppies to be performed at 6 and 10 weeks of age.
-Two puppies (ID# 8963,8926) born 1/26/2024 received a 5-way vaccine on 3/8/2024 and then on 3/23/2024. The PVC
prescribes for the 5-way vaccine for puppies to be performed at 6 and 10 weeks of age.
Failure to administer vaccines in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule can increase the risk of disease
exposure and disease transmission, and cause illness to the animals. Correct by ensuring all animals are vaccinated in
accordance with the guidelines and schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 15-April-2024.

The licensee is not maintaining complete medical records:
-Records indicate that a 5-year-old Poodle (ID# 7948) was dewormed on 10/14/2023 and 12/2/2023 but did not provide
any additional information including the name of the dewormer used.
-The licensee states that in October of 2023 they performed treatments on two Bernese Mountain Dog puppies including
topical ear treatments but could not provide documentation.
Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals
are receiving adequate veterinary care. Additionally, complete medical records ensure that all personnel at the facility are
clear on the plan for treatment and enables the licensee to evaluate effectiveness of the plan and ensure that the
condition is corrected. Complete medical records must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and
treatments administered and the dates of administration. Correct by documenting all treatments given to all animals and
ensure that medical records are complete and contain the required information.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The right eye of an adult male French Bulldog (ID# 8957) contained discharge and was not being treated. Mild amounts of 
yellow-green discharge were seen adjacent to the right eye. The eyelids of the right eye also appear to possibly be folding 
in on the eye (entropion). The animal was not seen scratching or irritating the site and was not squinting. The licensee 
states they have not been treating the eye. Failure to treat problems of animal health can lead to delays in providing 
proper care to animals resulting in worsening of their condition. The licensee must maintain programs of adequate 
veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
The licensee must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care at all times. Correct by ensuring that the 
animal is examined and treated by a licensed veterinarian. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the vaccination schedule in the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC): 
 
-Seven puppies (ID# 8970,8951,8975,8943,8934,8955,8965) born 1/10/2024 received a 5-way vaccine on 2/23/2024 and 
then on 3/9/2024. The PVC prescribes for the 5-way vaccine for puppies to be performed at 6 and 10 weeks of age. 
-Two puppies (ID# 8963,8926) born 1/26/2024 received a 5-way vaccine on 3/8/2024 and then on 3/23/2024. The PVC 
prescribes for the 5-way vaccine for puppies to be performed at 6 and 10 weeks of age. 
 
Failure to administer vaccines in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule can increase the risk of disease 
exposure and disease transmission, and cause illness to the animals. Correct by ensuring all animals are vaccinated in 
accordance with the guidelines and schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 15-April-2024. 
3.13(b)(3)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not maintaining complete medical records: 
 
-Records indicate that a 5-year-old Poodle (ID# 7948) was dewormed on 10/14/2023 and 12/2/2023 but did not provide

any additional information including the name of the dewormer used. 
-The licensee states that in October of 2023 they performed treatments on two Bernese Mountain Dog puppies including 
topical ear treatments but could not provide documentation.  
 
Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals 
are receiving adequate veterinary care. Additionally, complete medical records ensure that all personnel at the facility are 
clear on the plan for treatment and enables the licensee to evaluate effectiveness of the plan and ensure that the 
condition is corrected. Complete medical records must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and 
treatments administered and the dates of administration. Correct by documenting all treatments given to all animals and 
ensure that medical records are complete and contain the required information. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
